blocks.title: A text question for Page 5
blocks.description: You should only include a submit button on the second-to-last page. That way, the user will see a final ending page. If the app is configured to e-mail data, an e-mail will be sent each time the submit button is clicked.

blocks.title: Page 6
blocks.ask: Thank you for taking this survey. You really rock.
blocks.description: Because this set has no buttons, the participant will not be able to navigate to a different part of the survey.

blocks.title: Example Map
blocks.ask:
The interactive map to the left demonstrates the basic design and functionality of the maps you will see in the survey, although using silly map symbols.

Take some time to test out Map Interactions.

The interactive map includes three interactive features:

1. Zoom into and out of the map using your mouse wheel, double-clicking on the map, or using the zoom buttons to change the level of detail (zooming is constrained to only several scales).

2. Pan by grabbing and dragging the map to recenter on an area of interest (panning is constrained to the study area).

3. Retrieve details about the number of tweets at a specific location by clicking on the map.

Try each of these interactions now.

blocks.title: Participant Consent Form
blocks.ask:
Title of this Study: Elements of Interactive Cartography

Principle Investigator:
Robert E. Roth, PhD
375 Science Hall
N. Park Street
Madison, WI 53706
Phone: 608-262-1453; Email: reroth@wisc.edu

Description of Research:
You are invited to participate in a study to improve the design of interactive maps on the web. Specifically, the study investigates how we should design online maps that depict statistical information.

What will my participation involve?
If you decide to participate in this research, you will complete a survey that requires you to answer a series of tasks using different map designs. The survey will take approximately 25 minutes to complete.

Are there any risks to me?
Risk to participation is minimal. Thus, there are no foreseeable physical or mental risks to participation beyond those encountered in the normal course of everyday life.

Are there any benefits to me?
Your responses to the survey will be used to develop a better understanding of the design of interactive and online maps.

Will I be compensated for my time?
You will be compensated $3.50 for your participation upon completing the survey.

How will my confidentiality be protected?
No personally identifiable or sensitive information will be collected or maintained. Only group characteristics will be reported in publications of research findings.

Whom should I contact if I have questions?
You may ask any questions about the research at any time. If you have questions about the research after you leave today you should contact Robert E. Roth, PhD (PI) at 608-262-1453. If you are not satisfied with response of research team, have more questions, or want to talk with someone about your rights as a research participant, you should contact the Education Research and Social & Behavioral Science IRB Office at 608-263-2320. Your participation is completely voluntary and you can withdraw from the study at any time without compensation.

If you agree to take part in this research study as outlined above, please click 'Next' below. Selecting this button means that you understand your rights as a participant and AGREE to participate in this research study.

Close your browser if you choose NOT to participate.

blocks.title: Instructions and Eligibility
blocks.ask:
Thank you for agreeing to participate!

Maps and geographic information are increasingly common in daily life! You may be familiar with mapping services like Apple Maps, Google Maps, and MapQuest. You also may make use of web maps in social media like Facebook, Foursquare, Instagram, and Twitter. Further, you might have explored more complex interactive maps in popular news outlets like the New York Times and the Washington Post. The purpose of this study is to learn how we should design these maps.

INSTRUCTIONS
In the following survey, you will be shown different web map designs that depict the volume of tweets in Western Kansas. Twitter is a social media platform allowing users to submit short messages (i.e., tweets) that include a mappable location. The volume of tweets often is used as a proxy for public interest and engagement around different topics (e.g., entertainment, fashion, food, sports). The tweet topic will change from map to map, such that each tweet map pattern you will see is unique.

The survey has two sections:
  • First, you will be presented with an example map. You will be asked to interact with this map to explore it's functionality. You will not be tested on this map. It is for training purpsoes.
  • Second, you will be presented with 16 different maps and answer questions about map patterns as you interact with the maps. The map tasks are timed, so please do not divert your attention when completing the map tasks.
  • The survey closes with questions about your preferences, interests, and experiences. You will be compensated after completing the closing background survey.
You will be compensated after completing these sections and an exit survey!

ELIGIBILITY
Before beginning, please once again review your eligibility for participating in the study: These restrictions greatly impact your responses.
  • You must be 18 years of age or older.
  • You must be fluent in English.
  • You must currently be living in the United States, but not in Kansas due to familiarity with the tested Geography
  • You do not have color vision impairment (i.e., are colorblind).
  • You must complete the survey on a non-mobile device, such as a laptop or desktop computer. Completing the experiment on a smartphone or small screen tablet will greatly impact your performance and skew results.


Click “Next” to confirm that you have read the instructions and that you are eligible to participate in the study.
